This is a good catch. Thanks. I have added the exception handling and listener call. It is a pretty basic try..catch block. Please let me know if there are better way or convention to do it differently. Thanks.

I would've made this variable take both values in this test, i.e. don't rely on randomisation.
In principle, it's better to avoid randomisation for test coverage, and use it for variables that don't have any bearing on the output of the test. That's in principle, but sometimes the input value space is large and randomisation might be used on the independent variables as well (more often inside, but sometimes across, value spaces that change the outcome of the test).
Thanks that's a good point. I changed it to always test both situations.

I tried to remove the randomness, but then decided to keep it as is. Here is why: The intention is to test that "any local indices will be reported as hasLocalIndices". The "any" bit makes it more suitable for randomness, because it can be:

A single search context
Multiple search contexts where

the local one can be in the first position, second position, last position etc.
Or there might be more than one local contexts, e.g. all of them are local contexts or only one of them is not local context.



The randomness in the test is intended to cover all above situations. If removed, the coverage will be reduced (or we can replace it with a very bloated test method, but I think that is less ideal).

This test relies on the TransportSearchHelperTests#testParseScrollId , where, given SearchShardTargets, the scroll id is encoded and then decoded, and the test asserts that the "cluster alias" shows up after decoding.

nodes.bodyText: In principle, I would shy away from getters that do any processing, unless the method has a verb in the name.

Given TransportSearchHelper.parseScrollId(scrollId) can throw exception, I think it is fair to name it with a verb. I updated to be parseScrollId (same name as TransportSearchHelper#parseScrollId). The extra layer of proxy (from ParsedScrollId to TransportSearchHelper) is because TransportSearchHelper is not public and it feels better to keep it that way.

As you've mentioned the try-catch structure unfortunately doesn't fit too nicely with the async listener idiom .
I personally would've maintained a check like request instanceof SearchScrollRequest && ((SearchScrollRequest)request).scrollId() != null as I'm not a fan of catching runtime exceptions .
Again, this is a feedback with my perspective, the codebase is cot consistent in this regard; it's your choice.

I changed it to use ActionRunnable.supply(...).run(), which takes a CheckedSupplier to handle the exception. Honestly, the code is less readable with this change. But it is more in line with the overwhelming callback style.
The other option is to have SearchScrollRequest#parseScrollId catch the exception internally and returnnull if exception is thrown. But I am less favorable of this approach mainly because the actual exception is basically suppressed so that caller does not know what went wrong. In addition, it is trading a try-catch with a different try-catch plus a null check. Overall not necessarily better.
